Other monsters must be taken to the monster storage establishments where they can be kept or deleted. Each monster can also have up to 2 pieces of equipment placed on them.

At the end of every battle players earns experience points for themselves and each monster used. Also dropped by enemies is Pom which is money, items, etc. After being defeated players must view the opponents stats, and choose if they want to try and recruit them for their team which is based on the monsters negotiation stat & level. This mirrors the recruitment mechanics popularized by Dragon Quest V in 1992. Later on players get a journal for keeping a catalog of the 168 monsters in the game, though it's only about 50 with most monsters just having 3 color variations.

Storywise Zool is extremely text heavy and can be difficult to enjoy because of the Japanese text, though its gameplay is seemingly balanced for children as it is extremely easy and barebones with its combat.
title: Zool: Majū Tsukai Densetsu

description: Play through the 98/99 NBA season to build up your team over time. Or just jump straight to the playoffs. Trade, release or pick up free agents to add to your team. Have a bit of fun with the 3 point shootout mode. And a host of new player animations, including facial animations, and player moves.
title: NBA Live 99

description: Famista 64 is part of Namco's long-running Family Stadium franchise. Akin to other games in the series, Famista 64 features cutesy character designs and a more simplistic gameplay premise.
title: Famista 64

description: Flappy Bird is a homebrew and unlicensed version of Flappy Bird. The player plays as Bird. By flying through the pipes the player gets points. If the bird falls or touches something, the game is over.
title: Flappy Bird

description:
Fushigi no Dungeon: Fūrai no Shiren 2: Oni Shūrai! Shiren-jō! is the second game in the Shiren the Wanderer series which is part of Chunsoft's Mystery Dungeon series, and its only appearance on the Nintendo 64 platform.

The game is a traditional Roguelike game where you navigate through randomized maps to slay monsters, collect experience and items to accomplish certain tasks. When you die you can retain one item while experience is lost, there might however be ways to increase the number of items retained. You move in a turn-based grid like way where faster enemies are symbolized by getting multiple moves by turn, rather than actually faster movement.

Set before the events of the first game, Shiren and his weasel Kappa, on the way to the mountains, passes by the village of Natane, where they stop to eat. While eating a tribe of Demons attack. Pushing back against the attack Shiren decides to build a castle to defend the villagers from further attacks. The game revolves around building Castle Shiren. To do this you must seek out rare materials through the multiple dungeons that make up the game. Any progress to this meta goal is saved and progress is not redacted if you die on a run. Certain events trigger monsters to attack the village which you must help defend.

The game was originally planned to be a N64DD title, but development was later moved to the base N64.
title: Fushigi no Dungeon: Fūrai no Shiren 2: Oni Shūrai! Shiren-jō!

description:
This straightforward golf simulation has players taking on various Japanese golf courses on the pro tour. Officially licensed from the Japan Golf Tour association, it features a substantial lineup of real-world players using their 1998 data. Players can also create their own custom players and save that data on the game disk. Ten different officially-licensed golf courses from across Japan are playable, featuring accurate recreations of their real-world topography.

In addition to a single-player tournament mode, there are several different multiplayer modes. Two players can play together in a Match Play mode, and up to four can play together in the 18-hole Stroke Play mode. An online mode uses the 64DD's built-in modem to compete in a cross-country tournament with other players.
title: Japan Pro Golf Tour 64

description:
Derby Stallion 64 is a 1 - 4 player horse racing game for the Nintendo 64.

A combination horse racing business simulation and horse racing game, the player designs their own stable of horses, where they can customize the presentation of horse and jockey. These horses are entered into races, where the results of which determine monetary payout for the stable. The player must use their winnings to enhance their stable, purchase better horses, and compete in higher level races.
title: Derby Stallion 64

description: Saikyō Habu Shōgi is a simulation of the Japanese board game shōgi, released as one of the N64's three Japanese launch titles. It features the likeness of Yoshiharu Habu, then a prominent tournament player. Its board and game pieces are rendered in 3D, and the player can adjust the camera as they prefer.
title: Saikyō Habu Shōgi

description:
Eikō no St. Andrews is an immersive golf game that takes players on a journey through one of the oldest and most iconic golf courses in the world. Released in 1996 for the Nintendo 64 console in Japan only, this game offers players the unique opportunity to play a round of golf on the legendary "Old Course" at St Andrews, Scotland, which was established back in 1552.

As players start the game, they are greeted with stunning visuals that capture the lush green fairways and beautiful landscapes of the course. The game features realistic sound effects that mimic the sound of clubs hitting the ball and the gentle rustling of the wind through the trees.

Players can choose to play as one of several well-known golfers, each with their unique strengths and weaknesses. As they progress through the game, they can unlock new characters, clubs, and equipment that can help them improve their game and achieve their goal of winning the championship.

The game features several modes, including stroke play, match play, and tournament play. In stroke play, players aim to complete each hole in as few strokes as possible. Match play involves competing against an opponent, with the goal of winning more holes than the opponent. In tournament play, players compete against a large group of opponents, with the goal of achieving the lowest overall score.

Players must navigate through each hole, avoiding obstacles like bunkers, rough terrain, and water hazards. They can use a variety of clubs, including drivers, irons, and putters, to help them make their way through the course. Each shot requires careful consideration of the wind speed and direction, the slope of the terrain, and the distance to the hole.
title: Eikō no St. Andrews

description:
Mahjong Master is a simulation of the four-player tile-based game Mahjong.

In Mahjong Master, players take on the role of a skilled Mahjong player competing against other opponents in various tournaments. The game features three different modes: "Vs. Computer", "Vs. Human", and "Tutorial", each with its own unique challenges and gameplay mechanics.

In "Vs. Computer" mode, players can select from a variety of computer opponents, each with their own skill levels and playing styles. As players progress through the game, they will face increasingly difficult opponents, testing their skills and strategic thinking.

In "Vs. Human" mode, players can challenge their friends or family members to a game of mahjong using a split-screen display. This mode allows for up to four players to compete against each other, making it perfect for multiplayer gaming sessions.

Finally, the "Tutorial" mode is designed for beginners who are new to the game of Mahjong. This mode provides a step-by-step guide to the rules and gameplay mechanics of mahjong, allowing new players to learn the game at their own pace.
title: Mahjong Master

description:
64 Hanafuda: Tenshi no Yakusoku is a traditional Japanese card game.

Players use a set of Hanafuda cards to play various games against the computer or other players. Hanafuda cards are traditionally used in Japan for playing a variety of games and each card features a unique design that represents a flower, plant, or animal.

The game includes various modes such as Tournament, Exhibition, and Training - each with its own unique challenges and objectives. In Tournament mode, players can compete against other players in a Hanafuda tournament, trying to outscore their opponents by strategically using their cards. In Exhibition mode, players can play a single game against any opponent of their choice. The Training mode allows players to practice their skills and learn the game's rules and mechanics.
title: 64 Hanafuda: Tenshi no Yakusoku

description:
64 Trump Collection: Alice no Waku Waku Trump World is a unique card game that takes players on a journey through a whimsical and colorful world inspired by Lewis Carroll's classic novel, Alice in Wonderland.

Players use a set of cards to play various games against the computer or other players. The game features over 30 different card games, each with its own set of rules and challenges. These games include traditional card games like Poker and Blackjack, as well as unique and creative games that are exclusive to this title.

The game includes various modes such as Story, Free Play, and Training, each with its own unique challenges and objectives. In Story mode, players take on the role of Alice as she navigates her way through the magical world of Wonderland, playing card games with various characters she meets along the way. In Free Play mode, players can play any of the available card games against any opponent of their choice. The Training mode allows players to practice their skills and learn the game's rules and mechanics.
title: 64 Trump Collection: Alice no Waku Waku Trump World

description:
64 Ōzumō 2 is the sequel to the original 64 Ōzumō, bringing back the exciting world of traditional Japanese sumo wrestling to gaming enthusiasts.

Players once again take control of their choice of a sumo wrestler and compete against others in a variety of matches, including one-on-one matches, tag team matches, and battle royales. Players must use their skills and strategic thinking to push their opponents out of the ring or make them touch the ground with any body part other than their feet.

The game includes an expanded roster of wrestlers, each with their unique fighting styles, moves, and techniques. Players can choose to play as their favorite wrestlers or create their own character and customize their appearance, moves, and stats.

64 Ōzumō 2 features several game modes, including Exhibition, Tournament, and Story modes. In Exhibition mode, players can play a single match against any opponent of their choice. The Tournament mode allows players to participate in a full season of matches, competing against other wrestlers to win the championship. The Story mode offers a unique narrative experience, where players create their own wrestler and embark on a journey to become the ultimate sumo wrestling champion.

The game's graphics and sound design have been improved and updated from the original game. The game also includes a multiplayer mode, allowing players to compete against each other in local multiplayer matches.
title: 64 Ōzumō 2

description:
AI Shogi 3 is a strategic board game that brings the classic game of Shogi to the digital world.

Shogi, also known as Japanese Chess, is a two-player game that is played on a 9x9 board. In AI Shogi 3, players can challenge the computer or play against a friend in a game of Shogi.

The game features several modes, including Practice, Free Play, and Tournament modes. In Practice mode, players can hone their skills by playing against the computer at various difficulty levels. In Free Play mode, players can choose their opponent and play a casual game of Shogi. The Tournament mode allows players to compete in a series of matches against the computer to become the Shogi champion.

AI Shogi 3 includes a variety of game features, such as multiple move options, capturing pieces, and promoting pawns to powerful pieces, allowing players to execute various strategies and tactics to outsmart their opponents. The game also features an extensive library of tutorials and guides that help players learn the game's rules and strategies.
title: AI Shōgi 3

description:
Bass Rush: ECOGEAR Powerworm Championship is a fishing game that allows players to compete in a thrilling fishing tournament.

Players can choose their character from a diverse group of experienced fishermen and head out to various fishing locations to compete against other fishermen. The game features a variety of fishing modes, including Tournament, Practice, and Time Attack.

In Tournament mode, players compete against other fishermen to catch the biggest fish and win the championship. Practice mode allows players to hone their fishing skills, while Time Attack mode challenges players to catch as many fish as possible within a set time limit.

The game features a range of fishing equipment and lures, including the ECOGEAR Powerworm, a special lure designed to attract large bass. Players can choose the right bait, rod, and line for each fishing location to maximize their chances of catching big fish.

Bass Rush: ECOGEAR Powerworm Championship's graphics and sound design provide an immersive fishing experience. The game includes realistic water and weather effects, and players can use different camera angles to capture the perfect catch.

The game's controls use a simple button configuration that allows players to cast their line, reel in their catch, and adjust their rod's position with ease. Additionally, the game's AI provides a challenging opponent, with the fish responding to the player's movements and tactics.
title: Bass Rush: ECOGEAR Powerworm Championship

description:
Choro Q 64 2: Hacha-Mecha Grand Prix Race is a racing game developed for the Nintendo 64. As the title suggests, the game features the popular Choro Q toy cars in a fast-paced, action-packed racing experience.

Players can choose from a wide range of Choro Q cars, each with their unique characteristics and abilities. The game offers various modes of play, including Grand Prix mode, Time Attack mode, and VS mode, where players can compete against each other.

In Grand Prix mode, players compete in a series of races, with each race taking place in a different location and featuring different challenges and obstacles. The races range from simple laps around a track to more complex courses that require players to navigate through obstacles and hazards.

Time Attack mode challenges players to complete a set course as quickly as possible, with the best times recorded on a leaderboard. VS mode allows two players to race against each other on split-screen, adding an extra level of excitement and competition.

Choro Q 64 2 features a wide range of customization options, allowing players to modify their cars' performance and appearance. Players can upgrade their car's engine, tires, and other parts, as well as change the color and add stickers and decals.
title: Choro Q 64 2: Hacha-Mecha Grand Prix Race

description:
Chōkūkan Night: Pro Yakyū King 2 is a baseball simulation game with anime graphics. As the title suggests, the game is the second installment in the Pro Yakyū King series and offers an immersive and realistic baseball experience.

Players can choose from a wide range of real-life baseball teams, including all 12 teams from the Japan Professional Baseball League. The game features a variety of modes, including Exhibition mode, League mode, and Tournament mode, allowing players to experience the game in different ways.

In Exhibition mode, players can play a single game against a computer opponent or another player. League mode allows players to compete in a full season of games, with the ultimate goal of winning the championship. Tournament mode offers a variety of tournaments and challenges for players to participate in, with various rewards and prizes for successful players.

The gameplay mechanics are designed to provide an authentic baseball experience. Players can pitch, hit, and field with a variety of strategies and techniques, and the game's AI responds realistically to player actions. The game also includes various factors such as weather conditions, player fatigue, and stadium effects that can affect gameplay and add an extra level of challenge.
title: Chōkūkan Night: Pro Yakyū King 2

description:
Custom Robo is a single-player action game that takes place in a future world where small robots, called "Robos", are used for a variety of purposes including battling, exploration, and sport. The game follows the protagonist, who receives a custom Robo from their mother, and heads to the Robo Station to test it out with their friend Shinichi. The gameplay revolves around participating in a series of competitions to become the top Robo commander.

Players control a character who is part of a group that designs and battles with custom Robos. The game features a story mode where players progress through a series of battles against other Robo fighters. These battles take place in small, enclosed arenas, and players must use their Robos' unique abilities to defeat their opponents.

In addition to the story mode, Custom Robo also features a multiplayer mode that allows players to battle against each other with their custom Robos. The game features a robust customization system that allows players to modify every aspect of their Robos, including their appearance, weapons, and abilities.

Players can collect and purchase new parts and weapons throughout the game, allowing them to continually improve and customize their Robos. The game also features a variety of different Robo types, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.
title: Custom Robo

description:
Densha De Go!! 64 is a train simulation game that puts players in the role of a train operator, tasked with navigating various real-life train routes throughout Japan.

It has a dedicated controller to better replicate the controls of driving a real train. It features a large lever that serves as the train's throttle, allowing players to control the speed of the train. The lever can be pushed forward to accelerate and pulled back to slow down or stop the train. There are also buttons on the controller for activating the train's horn and emergency brakes.

The game includes a variety of real-life train routes from across Japan, each with its own unique characteristics and challenges. These routes range from short urban commuter lines to long-distance express trains that travel through scenic countryside.

Players must control the train's speed, braking, and acceleration to ensure a smooth and timely arrival at each station. They must also pay attention to traffic signals and other regulations to avoid accidents and delays. The game provides a heads-up display that shows key information such as the train's speed, distance to the next station, and time remaining until the next scheduled stop.

In addition to the main career mode, which offers increasingly challenging routes to progress through, the game also includes a free mode that allows players to explore and practice routes without any restrictions. The routes include detailed station layouts and surrounding environments that accurately depict real-life locations in Japan.

The game features authentic train models and realistic depictions of the Japanese landscape, including detailed station layouts and surrounding environments. The sound design includes realistic train sounds and announcements in Japanese.
title: Densha de Go! 64

description:
Doraemon 2: Nobita To Hikari No Shinden is an action-adventure and exploration game based on the popular anime and manga series, Doraemon, and follows the adventures of the titular robotic cat and his human friend, Nobita.

The gameplay involves exploration and puzzle-solving, as players navigate through various levels to collect items, defeat enemies, and solve challenges. The game features multiple playable characters, including Doraemon, Nobita, and their friends, each with unique abilities and skills.

The plot of the game revolves around the discovery of a hidden temple, where a mysterious treasure is said to be hidden. Doraemon and his friends embark on a quest to find the treasure, but they must first overcome a series of obstacles and challenges to reach their goal. Along the way, they must navigate through different environments, including forests, temples, and other mysterious places, battle enemies, and collect items to help them in their journey.
title: Doraemon 2: Nobita To Hikari No Shinden

description:
Doraemon 3: Nobita no Machi SOS! is based on the popular anime and manga series, Doraemon, and follows the adventures of the titular robotic cat and his human friend, Nobita. The game focuses on adventure and exploration, as players guide Doraemon and his friends through various challenges and puzzles to save the city of the future.

The game is set in various locations, including the city of the future and different time periods that players must travel through to progress through the game. The game's setting is largely influenced by the anime and manga series, which features a mix of futuristic and historical elements. The gameplay involves exploration and puzzle-solving, as players navigate through various levels to collect items, defeat enemies, and solve challenges. The game features multiple playable characters, including Doraemon, Nobita, and their friends, each with unique abilities and skills.

The game's plot revolves around the city of the future, which has been thrown into chaos by a mysterious force. Doraemon and his friends must travel through different time periods to gather clues and solve puzzles to restore order to the city and prevent a disaster from striking. Along the way, they must battle enemies, collect items, and interact with various characters to uncover the truth behind the mysterious force.
title: Doraemon 3: Nobita no Machi SOS!

description:
Hamster Monogatari 64 is a virtual pet simulation game and is a part of the "Hamster Monogatari" series; the only one that was released on the Nintendo 64 platform.

In the game, players take care of and raise their own hamsters. There are ten different types of hamsters to choose from, each with its own unique personality and appearance. Players must feed, play with, and take care of their hamsters to keep them healthy and happy. If you neglect their needs, they may become ill or injured. In that case, you can take them to the hospital to get treated.

To improve your hamsters' lives, you can visit the shop to purchase useful items or seek advice from the old shop owner. However, you need to be careful before buying anything because you can't return items once purchased. You can also enter your adult hamsters into competitions, either races or beauty competitions, where they can win prize money. But before entering, you need to check the calendar and apply in advance. If you have two adult hamsters of different genders, you can breed them in the breeding case. However, each hamster has a different personality, and if they are not compatible, it may not go well. Moreover, even if you put two hamsters in the breeding case, they may not necessarily have a pup.

One of the unique features of the game is the "Watch your Hamsters" option, where you can interact with your hamsters by petting them or teaching them tricks using your hand on the screen. With each week, you can advance to the next week and confirm your Hamster Raising Plan. Your mother will also give you 1000 yen every month to help with your hamster-raising expenses.

The game's story revolves around a young protagonist who can talk to hamsters. The game's concept may seem familiar to fans of the manga and anime "Hamtaro," but Hamster Monogatari 64 offers its own unique take on the concept. The story is set in a fantasy world where hamsters and their human owners live together. Players can enter this world by climbing down a hole in a big tree in a nearby forest.
title: Hamster Monogatari 64

description:
Heiwa Pachinko World 64 is a virtual pachinko game developed for the Nintendo 64 console. The game is set in a bright and colorful pachinko parlor where players can experience the thrill of playing one of Japan's most popular pastimes.

The game's objective is to gather basic knowledge about all the machines, combine that with knowledge about how the parlors operate, and which machines are paying out the most, then use that knowledge to exploit the game and win as much as possible.

In the game, players control a small ball that they shoot into a pachinko machine, a vertical pinball-like device. The ball bounces around the machine, hitting various pins and bumpers, and eventually falls into a scoring pocket. Players earn points based on where the ball lands, and can potentially win more balls to continue playing.

Heiwa Pachinko World 64 features a wide variety of pachinko machines, each with its own unique theme and gameplay mechanics. Players can choose from machines featuring popular anime and video game characters, as well as traditional Japanese motifs like cherry blossoms and koi fish. There are four machines featured: CR Success Story SP, Lemon Pie, CR Dama-chan House, and Bijyo Daishugo 2. The game allows you to check the pins with a free camera and offers a complete simulation with virtual parlors.

In addition to the standard pachinko gameplay, Heiwa Pachinko World 64 also includes a number of mini-games and challenges. For example, players can compete in a race to see who can score the most points in a set amount of time, or try to hit a series of specific targets to earn a bonus prize. The game offers three modes: Training Mode, where the jackpot probability is twice as high as the real machines, and you start playing with 500,000 yen; Battle Mode, where the jackpot probability is the same as the real machines, and you start with 100,000 yen; and Study Mode, where you can view things like the machines' rules, data, and Super Reach types.
title: Heiwa Pachinko World 64

description:
Ide Yōsuke no Mahjong Juku, also known as Yosuke Ide Mahjong Cram School, is a mahjong video game and features interactive replays of the games of the 1997 Autumn Seta Haisou Datsu Mahjong Japan Series. Yosuke Ide, a former Japanese Mahjong Champion, oversaw the game's development as a pro-Mahjong player, and the game's story mode competition spans over two years. The game is based on the teachings of the professional Japanese mahjong player, who serves as the game's instructor and guide.

The game promotes "healthy Mahjong" as a game that can be enjoyed by parents with their children, instead of a form of gambling. It offers a variety of modes, including a tutorial mode where players can learn the rules and basic strategies of mahjong, a challenge mode where players can test their skills against various opponents, and a story mode where players can follow Ide Yosuke's journey through the world of mahjong.

In the game's story mode, players compete against the Murakami family and their friends in a Mahjong tournament with various rules over two years. The game reflects on the particulars and manners of Mahjong, and the nature of the game, which are thoroughly supervised by Yosuke Ide.

In addition to traditional mahjong gameplay, the game also features several mini-games and challenges that test players' mahjong skills in unique ways. These include games like "Mahjong Solitaire" and "Mahjong Quiz", which add an extra layer of variety to the overall gameplay experience.
title: Ide Yōsuke no Mahjong Juku

description:
Itoi Shigesato no Bass Tsuri No. 1 Ketteihan! is a fishing simulation game developed in collaboration with Shigesato Itoi, a well-known writer and game designer in Japan.

The gameplay in Itoi Shigesato no Bass Tsuri No. 1 revolves around fishing for different types of fish in various locations across Japan. Players can choose from a variety of lures and fishing techniques to try and catch as many fish as possible, and the game also includes a "record book" feature that allows players to keep track of their catches.

In addition to the fishing gameplay, Itoi Shigesato no Bass Tsuri No. 1 also features a number of other activities for players to enjoy, such as exploring the game's various locations, interacting with other characters, and collecting items and achievements.

Itoi Shigesato no Bass Tsuri No. 1 Ketteihan! had a unique controller designed specifically for the game called the "Tsurikon 64". The Tsurikon 64 controller was shaped like a fishing reel and had a rod attached to it. The player would use the rod to cast their line and reel in fish, just like real fishing. The controller also had a small LCD screen that displayed information such as the time of day and the fish's weight, making the fishing experience more immersive. The Tsurikon 64 controller also had a vibration feature that would simulate the feeling of a fish biting the hook, which added to the realism of the game. The controller's buttons were used to select lures and perform other actions, and the joystick was used to control the movement of the line and the reel.
title: Itoi Shigesato no Bass Tsuri No. 1 Ketteihan!

description:
J-League Dynamite Soccer 64 is a soccer video game based on the J-League, which is the top professional soccer league in Japan.

The game features a wide range of gameplay modes, including Exhibition, League, Tournament, and Cup modes, allowing players to compete in various competitions and tournaments. Players can choose from a variety of J-League teams, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses, and take on opponents in exciting soccer matches. Players may pass, shoot, tackle, and perform other soccer moves with precision. The game also includes dynamic weather effects, such as rain and snow, which can affect gameplay and add an additional layer of challenge to matches.

In addition to its gameplay and graphics, J-League Dynamite Soccer 64 also offers a variety of customization options. Players can customize their team's formation, tactics, and strategy to suit their playing style. The game also includes a player creation feature, allowing players to create their own custom soccer player and lead them to glory on the field.
title: J-League Dynamite Soccer 64

description:
J-League Eleven Beat 1997 is a soccer video game with a focus on the J-League, the top-tier professional football league in Japan. Players can choose from various J-League teams, including well-known clubs such as Kashima Antlers, Yokohama Marinos, Urawa Red Diamonds, and more. The game features realistic player rosters and team formations based on the 1997 season of the J-League, offering an authentic representation of Japanese football at that time.

The gameplay is fast-paced, with players being able to perform various football moves, such as passes, dribbles, shots, and tackles, to outplay their opponents. The game also includes special moves, such as super shots or skillful dribbles, that can only be executed by certain players, adding an element of strategy to the gameplay. The game offers multiple game modes, including exhibition matches, league play, cup competitions, and training modes to hone players' skills. Additionally, there may be options for multiplayer gameplay, allowing players to compete against friends or family in exciting football matches.
title: J-League Eleven Beat 1997

description:
J-League Tactics Soccer is a soccer/football management game that allows players to take on the role of a coach and lead their favorite J-League team to victory. Players can choose from a variety of J-League teams, each with their own unique attack, speed, defense, and overall ratings. They can also create up to four custom players, choosing their names, faces, nationalities, ages, preferred foot, positions, roles, and stat attributes such as endurance, determination, kick power, pass, speed, and more.

The game features different modes, including J-League Mode, where players can guide their chosen team through a season, making strategic decisions on formations, lineups, and strategies during matches. Universal Cup Mode allows players to compete in a global tournament against teams from around the world, while Battle Mode lets them challenge friends in multiplayer matches. During matches, players can order their team to change strategies using the C buttons, and pause to make substitutions or watch replays.
title: J-League Tactics Soccer

description:
Jangō Simulation Mahjong-dō 64 is a mahjong simulation video game that aims to bring the traditional Japanese tile-based game of mahjong to the comfort of your own home. It is the third installment of the Mahjong series on the N64. The game features a cast of 16 characters, each with their own backstory and storylines to explore in the main mode. The characters are presented in an anime style. Play against challenging AI opponents or gather your friends for multiplayer matches, and test your skills and strategy.

Choose from a variety of different mahjong rule sets, including Riichi, Honitsu, Tanyao, and more, and customize the game to suit your preferences. With multiple game modes, such as Free Play, Tournament, and Campaign. The game also offers an extensive tutorial mode that guides both beginners and experienced players through the intricacies of mahjong, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. Another game mode is the "Strong Player Mode" where players aim to be the first to win 10 million G in 4-player Mahjong battles and take the title of "Fighting Spirit King." There is also a "Free Battle Mode" where players can freely set their own rules and characters, a "2-Player Mahjong Mode" with a story mode knockout tournament, and various environment settings and records modes to customize the gameplay experience.
title: Jangō Simulation Mahjong-dō 64

description:
Jikkyō GI Stable offers players a simulation of the world of Japanese horse racing.

As a player, you can choose to open a new stable or play the Original Stakes mode, where you can race, register, and edit your horses and jockeys. The game features famous racecourses in Japan, such as Tokyo, Nakayama, Kyoto, and Sapporo, each with different distances and course conditions, providing a realistic racing experience. With a large number of races held annually in Japan, players must strategically plan their racing career, manage their stable's finances, become skilled with the horse breeding system that allows you to create and customize your own bloodlines, and make training decisions to optimize their chances of success.

Players can choose to race with their own horse or jockey, participating in various types of horse racing, including flat racing, jump racing, and Ban'ei Racing, where horses must pull sleds up sand slopes. The game also offers options to register and edit horses and jockeys, allowing players to customize their stable and optimize their chances of winning prestigious races.
title: Jikkyō GI Stable

description:
Jikkyō J. League: Perfect Striker is a soccer video game and is the third title in the International Superstar Soccer series, and the first soccer game released on the Nintendo 64.

The main mode of the game is J League Challenge, where players play 30 matches from April to October, facing each team twice. The team with the most wins and goals at the end of the league wins. After completing the league, players can play a secret game against a new team. The game also features a penalty kick challenge mode, a tournament mode, and a training mode where players can practice various soccer skills. The game also offers various options, including game length, difficulty, sound, and commentary, which players can customize to their liking. Jikkyō J. League: Perfect Striker allows players to create and edit players and teams, trade players and teams between controller paks, and delete registered/created players.
title: Jikkyō J. League: Perfect Striker

description:
Jikkyō J-League 1999: Perfect Striker 2 is a soccer simulation video game and features Japanese J.League teams and rosters from the 1999 season, including 16 clubs in J1 and 10 clubs in J2. In addition to the J.League teams, plus -- there are secret teams that can be unlocked within the game.

The game offers several modes, including preseason (match and mini-cup), J.League (start and load), tournament, success (Football Mania), PK, scenario, training (match, FK, CK, catch), and option. In preseason mode, players can set their status, including condition, number of players, keeper level, and motivation. In-match options include selecting a team, changing formation and camera, and setting up strategies for offense and defense. The game features professional commentary. Players can only play against the CPU.
title: Jikkyō J-League 1999: Perfect Striker 2

description:
Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū 4 is a baseball simulation game. It features a variety of game modes, including Exhibition, Season, All-Star Game, and Home Run Derby. Players can choose from a roster of fictional teams, each with their own unique set of players and abilities.

Players can control every aspect of their team, from pitching and batting to fielding and base-running. In addition to the core gameplay, Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū 4 also features a variety of mini-games and bonus modes. These include a batting practice mode, a home run derby mode, and a variety of skill challenges that test the player's ability to hit, catch, and throw the ball.
title: Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū 4

description:
Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū 5 is a baseball simulation game developed as part of the long-running Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū series, which is a popular baseball franchise in Japan. Players can create and customize their own baseball team, choosing from a wide range of players with unique abilities and stats. The game features a variety of modes, including Exhibition, Pennant Race, and Home Run Derby. Players can also compete against each other in multiplayer mode.

The game simulates the various aspects of baseball, including pitching, hitting, fielding, and base running. Players must strategically manage their team and make quick decisions on the field to win games. The game also features commentary from professional baseball announcers.
title: Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū 5

description: Portal 64 is an unofficial, homebrew demake of Portal built for Nintendo 64 hardware using the official SDK, Libultra. The initial version consisted of remade versions of the first 13 chambers of the original game, with the remaining portions still in development. Unfortunately, Valve requested that developer James Lambert take the project down, less because of the use of their own IP and more because of potential litigation from Nintendo because of the use of the SDK.
title: Portal 64: The First Slice

description:
In this sequel to Virtual Pro Wrestling, wrestlers worldwide gather once again to fight it all out. The game has many similarities to WCW vs. nWo: World Tour. The new roster contains a total of 78 real-life wrestlers from seven different organizations, plus 16 unlockable legends. In addition, the player has the ability to customize a wrestler cosmetically and statistically. The game plays in six different modes:

  • Champion Road - From six different wrestling organizations, the player must beat all opponents who hold the champion title to become top champion.
  • Exhibition - This can be played in single, tag team, or handicap matches. Game rules are configurable.
  • Elimination - With a group of five select wrestlers, the player battles in team matches against an opposing group of five.
  • Battle Royale - Four wrestlers fight simultaneously in the ring with the last man standing being the winner.
  • League - With a total of 16 wrestlers as tag teams, the player must beat every single team to get the highest in the league.
  • Tournament - 16 different wrestlers battle in 8 bracket structured matches for the highest ranking.
title: Virtual Pro Wrestling 64

description: A sugoroku-esque board game in which group of young children pretend to be detectives within the confines of their home. On their turn, players roll a die and advance that many spaces on the board, even over already traveled tiles. Depending on where they land, they can collect clues, manage stats, etc. Should two players land on the same space, they duel with whatever cards they've collected until that point.
title: Kiratto Kaiketsu! 64 Tanteidan
